substandard_descriptions.8.A.1a: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.
substandard_descriptions.8.A.1b: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.
substandard_descriptions.8.A.1c: Parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.1a: Verify that angle measure, betweeness, collinearity and distance are preserved under rigid transformations.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.1b: Investigate if orientation is preserved under rigid transformations.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.5b: Explore the relationship between the interior and exterior angles of a triangle.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.5c: Construct and explore the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.5a: Derive the sum of the interior angles of a triangle.
substandard_descriptions.7.RP.2a: Decide whether two quantities are in a proportional relationship, e.g., by testing for equivalent ratios in a table or graphing on a coordinate plane and observing whether the graph is a straight line through the origin.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.2a: Describe a possible sequence of rigid transformations between two congruent figures.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.4a: Describe a possible sequence of transformations between two similar figures.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.5d: Use the properties of similar figures to solve problems.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.6a: Explain why the slope (m) is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the Cartesian coordinate plane.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.6b: Derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.
substandard_descriptions.7.RP.2b: Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships.
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.8a: Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.5a: Interpret the unit rate as the slope of the graph.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.8a: Graph systems of linear equations and recognize the intersection as the solution to the system.
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.7a: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.8b: Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection. For example, 3x + 2y = 5 and 3x + 2y = 6 have no solution because 3x + 2y cannot simultaneously be 5 and 6.
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.8c: Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables. For example, given coordinates for two pairs of points, determine whether the line through the first pair of points intersects the line through the second pair.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.7b: Solve linear equations and inequalities with rational number coefficients, including equations and inequalities whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and combining like terms.
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.7b: Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients, including equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.7a: Create and identify linear equations with one solution, infinitely many solutions or no solutions.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.8b: Explain why solution(s) to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to point(s) of intersection of the graphs.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.8c: Explain why systems of linear equations can have one solution, no solution or infinitely many solutions.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.8d: Solve systems of two linear equations.
substandard_descriptions.8.A.3b: Recognize that the graph of a linear function has a constant rate of change.
substandard_descriptions.8.B.4b: Determine the parameters of a linear function.
substandard_descriptions.8.B.4a: Explain the parameters of a linear function based on the context of a problem.
substandard_descriptions.8.GM.9b: Understand the concepts of volume and find the volume of pyramids, cones and spheres.
substandard_descriptions.8.A.3a: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose parameters are the slope (m) and the y-intercept (b).
substandard_descriptions.8.DSP.4a: Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects.
substandard_descriptions.8.DSP.4b: Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.
substandard_descriptions.5.NBT.3a: Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 x 100 + 4 x 10 + 7 x 1 + 3 x (1/10) + 9 x (1/100) + 2 x (1/1000).
substandard_descriptions.5.NF.5b: Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (nxa)/(nxb) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.4b: Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.4a: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used.
substandard_descriptions.7.NS.2d: Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.2b: Evaluate square roots of perfect squares less than or equal to 625 and cube roots of perfect cubes less than or equal to 1000.
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.2a: Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that √2 is irrational.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.2c: Recognize that square roots of non-perfect squares are irrational.
substandard_descriptions.8.EE.2b: Simplify numerical radicals, limiting to square roots (i.e. nonperfect squares). For example, simplify √8 to 2√2.
substandard_descriptions.8.EEI.2a: Solve equations of the form x^2 = p and x^3 = p, where p is a positive rational number.
substandard_descriptions.8.NS.1b: Understand that all rational numbers have a decimal expansion that terminates or repeats.
substandard_descriptions.8.NS.1c: Convert decimals which repeat into fractions and fractions into repeating decimals.

Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 x 100 + 4 x 10 + 7 x 1 + 3 x (1/10) + 9 x (1/100) + 2 x (1/1000).

Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (nxa)/(nxb) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.
